Today, I introduced a bill here in Congress, along with Senator James Lankford in the Senate, to block legalizing physician-assisted suicide in D.C. As a physician of over 25 years, access to quality healthcare for every American is a concern that is close to my heart. By authorizing doctors to violate the Hippocratic Oath of “do no harm,” I believe physician-assisted suicide undermines a key safeguard that protects our nation’s most vulnerable citizens and ensures our loved ones receive the best medical care when they need it most.    Congress has the responsibility under the U.S. Constitution and the D.C. Home Rule Act to review actions by the District of Columbia. If we failed to act, it would would imply federal approval of physician-assisted suicide – which is not the right path. Today, we celebrated life. But we also pause to remember lives lost. On the anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz, may we never forget those who died in the horrors of the Holocaust, may we honor those who survived, and may we use this anniversary as a reminder so that history will never repeat itself.

Today, hundreds of thousands of Americans marched the streets of Washington, D.C -- taking a stand for life. Hundreds of thousands of voices echoed across the National Mall – speaking out for those whose voices are silenced.   Here in the Rayburn House Office Building where I work, over 700 citizens from the 1st and 2nd Districts of Ohio gathered – celebrating the sacred gift of life.   As a physician and a public servant, I’m proud to be a part of this fight. If you weren’t able to make it to D.C., here are a few of my favorite moments from today:

After serving in Iraq, I had the honor of sponsoring and assisting two Iraqi citizens seeking asylum in the United States. After working on behalf of the United States as interpreters in our hospital in Iraq, their lives were in jeopardy if they remained in their own country. Today, they and their families are U.S. citizens. Their children are bilingual and beautiful. Both men are practicing physicians here today in our United States – productive citizens and proud Americans. Having worked with these gentlemen for one year under extreme and often intense circumstances in Iraq, I was confident in their character as they went through extensive vetting before coming to the United States.  On the other hand, the reality is that there are many in their land who want to kill Americans and bring harm to our nation. I witnessed this firsthand serving in Iraq. Regardless of the amount of kindness we extended -- especially as physicians and nurses -- many of the citizens we cared for expressed gratitude for their medical care while still maintaining their desire to kill us.  As we have seen, Americans are increasingly at risk at home and abroad. Our intelligence sources have identified certain unstable countries as higher risk of terrorists attempting to enter the United States. Our intelligence officials have, for some time, confirmed the inadequacy of our vetting procedures. That’s why, on Friday, the administration issued an executive action ordering a 90-day pause (not a permanent ban) and reevaluation of our screening process of people traveling to the U.S. from seven war-torn countries and a 120-day pause and reevaluation of our refugee resettlement program. The nations identified do not yet have the ability to assist us with sufficient data on those attempting to enter the United States, thus increasing the risk, and have been designated by the Department of Homeland Security pursuant to U.S. law as being “countries of concern”  under the Obama administration. Attempts by declared jihadists to blend in with refugees is well understood.  A temporary pause and reevaluation of refugee programs is consistent with the previous administration’s actions, which temporarily paused the Iraqi refugee program after discovering a terror plot in Kentucky being launched by two Iraqi refugees. While thoughtful clarifications are needed to address any unintended consequences of the administration’s order, taking a comprehensive look at our vetting process is a commonsense security measure.  I do believe that those with green cards and those that have stood in support of our men and women in uniform deserve special consideration and accommodation, and I urge the administration to make resolving the cases of individuals who served alongside U.S. troops a top priority.   Bottom-line: Our compassion must not come at the cost of our national security -- but our security must also never cost us our national identity. Let’s take a deep breath, remedy any unintended consequences, and work to enhance the safety of our families while continuing to be a beacon of hope for persecuted people of the world who seek refuge in free lands.

ICYMI: The Department of Defense Inspector General released their report today on allegations of the manipulation of intelligence at Central Command (CENTCOM).  Some backstory: In response to these whistle-blower allegations, the Chairmen of the House Armed Services Committee, House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, and the Subcommittee on Defense of the House Appropriations Committee set up a Joint Congressional Task Force led by Reps. Ken Calvert, Mike Pompeo, and myself.   In August of last year, our task force released initial findings that intelligence products on the U.S. counter-ISIS mission were more positive than the assessments being produced by rest of the Intelligence Community, and the widespread internal perception that analysts’ assessments were being distorted was inadequately addressed by CENTCOM leadership.   Today, the Department of Defense Inspector General publicly released the findings of its own independent investigation, which confirm many of the deficiencies highlighted by the Congressional report.  Ultimately, there were both personal and institutional lessons learned from these investigations. It is critical that Congress follows up on the deficiencies highlighted by both independent investigations to ensure our warfighters are supported with the best analysis and most accurate intelligence possible in their continued fight to defeat radical Islamic terrorism. I will continue working with my colleagues on the House Armed Services Committee and the Intelligence Committee to ensure that is the case.

It was an honor to speak at Extremity War Injuries XII: Homeland Defense as a Translation of War Lessons Learned, a forum focusing on the preparedness of our troops and military medical professionals.  Having served as a combat surgeon in Iraq myself, making sure our uniformed medical professionals are adequately prepared for the trauma they will treat in combat environments when they are deployed is a priority of mine in Congress. In the most recent defense policy bill, which President Obama signed into law this past December, I worked to secure language to help create partnerships allowing military trauma surgeons and physicians to embed within civilian trauma centers to treat critically injured patients.   This does two important things: 1) It helps ensure trauma providers in the U.S. Armed Forces maintain medical readiness and rapid deployability for future conflicts and 2) it helps ensure that the incredible achievements and skills of our military medical professionals, honed in combat environments, are being harnessed for the benefit of our larger communities here at home.

Today, the House Veterans Affairs Committee is “marking up” multiple bills to hold the VA accountable and make sure we are better serving our veterans. One of the bills is H.R. 1367 that I introduced to streamline and update VA hiring processes. In order to provide our veterans with the best quality medical care, the VA must be recruiting and retaining the best medical professionals.

Marking up another bill I introduced – The Veterans Second Amendment Protection Act. This bill fixes a bureaucratic failure within the VA that can wrongly deny veterans their Second Amendment rights. We need to keep necessary safeguards in the system, but for the men and women who have worn the uniform of this country to be wrongly denied the very constitutional freedoms that they fought for is unconscionable.

A quick round up of facts in light of the Armed Services Committee hearing today on the impact stop-gap budgeting has on our military:  Right now, 53% of all Navy aircraft cannot fly -- due to increased operations and a shortage of funding, maintenance, and parts.   In 2015, Marine Corps aviation deaths hit a five-year high as aircraft failed or pilots made mistakes due to inadequate training hours.   The Vice Chief of Staff of the Army recently testified that “our Army requires modernized equipment to win decisively – but today we are outranged, outgunned, and outdated.”  For too long, we’ve taken our military for granted. We’re resourcing its current missions – such as counter-ISIL operations – but failing to fully invest in the modernization, maintenance, and capabilities that they will need to combat and defuse future threats. The impact of this is not readily visible to the public – but it comes at a cost for our warfighters, as we heard in testimony today. The House already passed defense appropriations (with a huge bipartisan vote) to begin to give troops the capabilities they need. Now, the Senate needs to take it up immediately and send it to the President’s desk.

Here’s what I think: we need to add an additional layer of personal accountability to both chambers of Congress. That’s why I introduced the Do Your Job Act last Congress to withhold lawmakers’ pay if they fail to vote on 12 individual spending bills by the October 1st deadline. I will be reintroducing the bill this year, and hope the American people help galvanize support for this tool for motivating Congress to finish its appropriations process on time.

As new reports continue to make headlines, here's my take:  One of Congress’ key roles has always been to conduct oversight of the executive branch, regardless of what party is in power. Both the allegations against the administration and the fact that purported classified information is being leaked to the media warrant thorough investigation and oversight, which is why I support the House Oversight Committee’s efforts to gather relevant materials, memos, and witness testimonies. I will also continue to support and engage in the ongoing investigations by the Senate and House Intelligence Committees, as well as the DOJ and FBI. Our job as representatives of the American people is not to jump to conclusions or play into the hysteria of the 24-hour news cycle. Our job is to get the facts – responsibly, dispassionately, thoughtfully, and thoroughly.    We need to put speculation and media spin aside. The American public deserves transparency and they deserve the truth: “Truth, justice, and the American way." That will continue to be my focus, along with doing the job my constituents sent me here to do: working to jump-start the economy, streamline the tax code, care for our veterans, and protect national security.

Tonight, Secretary of Defense Mattis is testifying before the House Armed Services Committee for the first time. My take: the defense budget has been cut by more than 20% since 2010, but the world hasn’t gotten any safer. Our men and women in uniform have made do for the past decade: cutting back on training hours and taking parts off other planes, ships and units to get planes, ships and equipment ready to deploy to the Middle East and across the globe. But those cutbacks have a real cost. In 2015, Marine Corps aviation deaths hit a five-year high as aircraft failed or pilots made mistakes due to inadequate training hours. Additionally, our Navy fleet is among the smallest since WWI, which means longer deployments, compounding stress on our ships, our sailors, and their families. Average deployment time has gone up roughly 30 percent in recent years, according to the Navy.  We can’t afford to continue to force our military to choose between meeting current operational requirements and meeting the challenges of tomorrow. We need to invest in the resources, equipment, and training our warfighters need to respond to conflict around the globe today, and also critical, cutting-edge capabilities they will need tomorrow.

Friends -- many of you have seen my statement on my website about the president's DACA decision, but I wanted to share a few further thoughts as well...  Here’s my take: I have great compassion for the young people who were brought to this country illegally through no fault of their own. At the end of the day, we are a nation of immigrants. We are also a nation of laws. But we’ve never been a nation that holds children legally responsible for the actions of their parents.   DACA was a controversial and unconstitutional executive mandate. On top of that, it was never intended to be permanent – President Obama himself called it a “temporary stopgap measure.” Whatever the intention, stop-gap measures rarely result in solid, long-term policy.    Unfortunately, DACA has only exacerbated our immigration problems and contributed to the confusion. By rescinding the program with a  six month wind-down period, the administration is taking a step to restore the proper balance of powers. The Constitution is pretty straightforward about this in Article 1, Section 1, “All legislative Powers herein granted shall be vested in a Congress of the United States, which shall consist of a Senate and House of Representatives.”   What we need now is legislative action, which comes from the American people through their representatives in Congress. It has long been, and still is, my position that our top priorities should be securing our porous southern border and developing a legal immigration system that is beneficial to all Americans and those seeking to become Americans. Addressing the status of those in this country illegally also needs to be part of that conversation. It’s time to tackle these tough issues and work together towards long-term solutions that can be passed into law and signed by the president.   Let’s continue to uphold our national identity as a country that welcomes “your tired, your poor, your huddled masses yearning to breathe free…” but let’s do it legally. Let’s protect the innocent, and work to develop a system where children are no longer put in such a position in the first place.

September is National Suicide Prevention Month. It is a time for our country to collectively pause, reflect, and reevaluate how we can better provide Americans who are contemplating ending their lives with the resources and medical care they need to give them hope, and to help them know they are not alone.   Today, as part of that conversation, Democrats and Republicans gathered to discuss a bipartisan bill about the dangers of legalizing physician-assisted suicide. I introduced this bill (H.Con.Res. 80) along with 9 of my colleagues from both sides of the aisle, because we believe Americans deserve better.   Protecting the vulnerable and providing quality care for all patients are cornerstones of any good healthcare system. Included in that is providing comfort and care for those facing the heart-wrenching challenges of dealing with a potentially terminal illness. But physician-assisted suicide does the opposite. It undermines a key safeguard that protects our nation’s most vulnerable citizens, including the elderly, people with disabilities, and people experiencing psychiatric diagnoses. It leaves patients unprotected. It prioritizes cost over compassion – potentially incentivizing payers to encourage death or care or cure.   That’s why I’m working with this bipartisan group of members to help promote greater awareness of the dangers of physician-assisted suicide, while giving voice to those who are put at most risk by the continued spread of this dangerous practice. I will continue to defend every human being’s inherent dignity, and work to ensure patients facing the possible or probable end of their lives have access to the best quality and most comprehensive medical care possible, including palliative, in-home, or hospice care, tailored to their individual needs.   When governments support, encourage, or facilitate suicide – whether assisted by physicians or others – we devalue our fellow citizens, our fellow human beings.   That is not who we are, and that is not who we should be.

Shoop was born in New Jersey in 1921 and moved to Washington Court House, OH at age 3 and has since been a longtime resident of Lynchburg, OH. On October 20, 1940, Harry entered active duty service with the Ohio National Guard and was assigned to Ohio’s 37th Infantry Division and then to the 38th Infantry Division. While on active duty, Harry rose through the ranks and was promoted to platoon sergeant in both companies B & H with the 149th Infantry Regiment. During the re-taking of the Philippines during the infamous battle of Zig Zag Pass, Mr. Shoop and his unit saw 198 consecutive days of combat. This is where Harry’s hand was hit be enemy fire – but he quickly wrapped his hand and continued to fight. Harry spent 6 weeks in the 80th General Hospital in Manilla. He was honorably discharged from active duty on November 9, 1945 as Technical Sargent.  71 years later, on August 7, 2017, Harry Shoop received the medals that he earned in service to this country. During the medal ceremony that I was honored to participate in, Harry said this:  “I give thanks, in my humble way, to the United States of America and the people in it because you are the people that are America. I’m proud of each and every one of you, and I’m proud of the ones I’ve known in the past. The United States of America will always come first.”  Harry – thank you for your service.

Today's OH2 veteran spotlight:  Name: Frank Buschmeier Branch: U.S. Army Hometown: Milford, OH Story: Frank W. Buschmeier was born in Milford, OH in 1923 and entered active duty service on January 27, 1943 – at age 19. He was trained as a flight crew member with the United States Army Air Corps, assigned to the 100th Bomber Group, 350th Bomb Squadron. Frank was then attached to the Gibbon’s Crew (named for pilot 2nd LT John Gibbons) with the Boeing B-17G Flying Fortress – the plane was affectionately named “Miss Irish”. Sgt. Frank Buschmeier served as a ‘left waist gunner’ aboard the Miss Irish. On March 19, 1944, the Miss Irish was shot down by German flak, but the experienced and calm flight crew was able to successfully land the plane. This terrifying experience was just one of many harrowing situations Sgt. Buschmeier would endure in battle. The remaining crewmembers of the Miss Irish were assigned to another plane. On July 29, 1944, while on their 34th “pick up” mission, they were shot down over Merseberg, Germany. This time, Sgt. Buschmeier was captured by the German army and held captive for 10 months in a German prison camp. Frank was honorable discharged from the U.S. Army Air Corps on October 29, 1945.   At the time of his discharge, Sgt. Frank Buschmeier was issued the Purple Heart Award, the Distinguished Flying Cross, the Air Medal with 4 bronze clusters, and the European-African-Middle Eastern medla with 3/bronze battle star attachments.   On May 10, 2013, it was my honor to present Sgt. Frank Buschmeier with his remaining three medals that he earned in service to this country: the Army Good Conduct Medal, the Prisoner of War Medla, and the American Campaign Medal.  Frank – thank you for your service.
